def: A family ${\mathcal A} \subset {\mathcal P}[n]$ satisfies an $x_{ij}$-\emph{pairwise restriction} between layers $i$ and $j$ of the cube if $|A\setminus B| \neq x_{ij}$ for all $A\in {\mathcal A}^{(i)}$ and $B \in {\mathcal A}^{(j)}$.
plain_text_def: A family 𝒜⊂𝒫[n] satisfies an x_ij-pairwise restriction between layers i and j of the cube if |A∖ B| ≠ x_ij for all A∈𝒜^(i) and B ∈𝒜^(j).
masked_plain_text_def: A family 𝒜⊂𝒫[n] satisfies an x_ij-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM between layers i and j of the cube if |A∖ B| ≠ x_ij for all A∈𝒜^(i) and B ∈𝒜^(j).

def:
\label{def2.1} If  $\Delta$ is a plane semi-triangulation, $d$ is a fixed vertex of $\sigma(\Delta)$, and $D$ is a fixed  subset of $V(\Delta)$, then a triple $[\Delta, d, D]$ (or $[\Delta, d]$ for $D = \emptyset$) is called a \emph{pattern}.

We say that a patern $[\Delta, d, D]$ is \textsl{$\sigma$-compatible} with a patern $[\Gamma, g, W]$ if there exists an isomorphism $\varphi: \sigma(\Delta)\rightarrow \sigma(\Gamma)$ such that $\varphi(\sigma(\Delta))$ and $\sigma(\Gamma)$ have the same orientation, $\varphi(d) = g$, $\varphi(D\cap V(\sigma(\Delta)) = W \cap V(\sigma(\Gamma))$, and,  if $x y$ is a chord of $\sigma(\Delta)$, then $\varphi(x)\varphi(y)$ is a chord of $\sigma(\Gamma)$.

We write $[\Delta, d, D] = [\Gamma, g, W]$ if there exists an isomorphism $\varphi\colon  \Delta \rightarrow \Gamma$ such that $\varphi(\sigma(\Delta))$ and $\sigma(\Gamma)$ have the same orientation, $\varphi(d) = g$ and $\varphi(D) = W$.
plain_text_def:
If  Δ is a plane semi-triangulation, d is a fixed vertex of σ(Δ), and D is a fixed  subset of V(Δ), then a triple [Δ, d, D] (or [Δ, d] for D = ∅) is called a pattern.

We say that a patern [Δ, d, D] is σ-compatible with a patern [Γ, g, W] if there exists an isomorphism φ: σ(Δ)→σ(Γ) such that φ(σ(Δ)) and σ(Γ) have the same orientation, φ(d) = g, φ(D∩ V(σ(Δ)) = W ∩ V(σ(Γ)), and,  if x y is a chord of σ(Δ), then φ(x)φ(y) is a chord of σ(Γ).

We write [Δ, d, D] = [Γ, g, W] if there exists an isomorphism φΔ→Γ such that φ(σ(Δ)) and σ(Γ) have the same orientation, φ(d) = g and φ(D) = W.
masked_plain_text_def:
If  Δ is a plane semi-triangulation, d is a fixed vertex of σ(Δ), and D is a fixed  subset of V(Δ), then a triple [Δ, d, D] (or [Δ, d] for D = ∅) is called a B_MATH_TERM.

We say that a patern [Δ, d, D] is σ-compatible with a patern [Γ, g, W] if there exists an isomorphism φ: σ(Δ)→σ(Γ) such that φ(σ(Δ)) and σ(Γ) have the same orientation, φ(d) = g, φ(D∩ V(σ(Δ)) = W ∩ V(σ(Γ)), and,  if x y is a chord of σ(Δ), then φ(x)φ(y) is a chord of σ(Γ).

We write [Δ, d, D] = [Γ, g, W] if there exists an isomorphism φΔ→Γ such that φ(σ(Δ)) and σ(Γ) have the same orientation, φ(d) = g and φ(D) = W.

def:
[Section 4 of \cite{W}]
Let $f=\sum_{S\subseteq[m]} c(S) \x^S$ be multiaffine with real nonnegative
coefficients, and assume that $f$ is Rayleigh.\\
\textup{(a)}\ The support $\supp(f)$ is a convex delta-matroid.\\
\textup{(b)}\ The coefficients are \emph{log-submodular}:\ for all
$A,B\subseteq[m]$,
$$
c(A\cap B) c(A\cup B) \leq c(A) c(B).
$$
plain_text_def:
[Section 4 of <cit.>]
Let f=∑_S⊆[m] c(S) ^S be multiaffine with real nonnegative
coefficients, and assume that f is Rayleigh.

 The support (f) is a convex delta-matroid.

 The coefficients are log-submodular: for all
A,B⊆[m],

    c(A∩ B) c(A∪ B) ≤ c(A) c(B).

 The coefficients are B_MATH_TERM: for all
A,B⊆[m],

def:
For $1 \leq j \leq t$, define 
\[E_j = f^{-1}(j) = \{ \{u,v\} \in E: f(\{u,v\}) = j\}\] and let $V_j$ be the vertices
spanned by $E_j$.
$(V_j,E_j)$ is a graph that we term the {\em $j$th key graph}.

%Clearly, for any edge $\{u,v\} \in E_j$,  users $u$ and $v$ each must store 
%one of $R_{j}$ or $L_{u,v}$. 
Let \[W_j = \{ v \in V_j : v \mbox{ stores } R_j\}\]
and define  $\W = (W_1, \dots , W_t)$. 
Since we are assuming that $f$ is surjective, it follows that
$|E_j| \geq 1$ and $|V_j| \geq 2$ for all $j \in \{1, \dots , t\}$.
%and let
%\[W'_j = V_j \backslash W_j.\]

An IOS is fully specified by 
$f$ and $\W$, so we will refer to  $(f,\W)$ as a \emph{$G$-IOS}.

def: Let $G$ be a group of order $v$, written multiplicatively, and let $D$ be a subset of $G$ with $k$ elements. Then $D$ is a $(v,k,\lambda,n)$-\emph{difference set in $G$} if the multiset $\{d_1 d_2^{-1}: d_1, d_2 \in D \text{ and } d_1 \ne d_2 \}$ contains every non-identity element of $G$ exactly $\lambda$ times. In this case, we define $n:=k- \lambda$.
plain_text_def: Let G be a group of order v, written multiplicatively, and let D be a subset of G with k elements. Then D is a (v,k,λ,n)-difference set in G if the multiset {d_1 d_2^-1: d_1, d_2 ∈ D  and  d_1  d_2 } contains every non-identity element of G exactly λ times. In this case, we define n:=k- λ.

In this case, we define n:=k- λ.

def:
\label{def:crosscritical}
Let $c$ be a positive integer.
A graph $G$ is \emph{$c$-crossing-critical} if $cr(G)\ge c$, but every proper
subgraph $G'$ of $G$ has $cr(G')<c$.
plain_text_def:
Let c be a positive integer.
A graph G is c-crossing-critical if cr(G)≥ c, but every proper
subgraph G' of G has cr(G')<c.

subgraph G' of G has cr(G')<c.

poly(n), where poly(n) is a polynomial factor.

Algorithm <ref> computes a (min(c,(c/2)^ϵ),Λ,ϵ)-m-sequence which is (log(cn)-2)-big and runs in time O(h(A^m)n^1-ϵ) + 
B_MATH_TERM(n), where B_MATH_TERM(n) is a polynomial factor.

def:
Suppose $P$ is a tree and $k,l< \omega$.  Suppose also that there exist ordinals $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ such that $$\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot\ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}.$$      Then for any function $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$,  there exist a subtree $Q$ of $P$ and a function $F:l+1\to k+1$ such that $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q)=\text{\emph{rank}}(P)$ and for each $(s,t)\in \Lambda_2(Q)$,   $\varsigma_Q(s,t)=\varsigma_P(s,t)$ and $F(\varsigma_Q(s,t))=f(s,t)$. 

\label{main1}
plain_text_def:
Suppose P is a tree and k,l< ω.  Suppose also that there exist ordinals _0⩾…⩾_l such that 
    rank(P)=ω^ω^_0·…·ω^ω^_l.
      Then for any function f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1,  there exist a subtree Q of P and a function F:l+1→ k+1 such that rank(Q)=rank(P) and for each (s,t)∈Λ_2(Q),   ς_Q(s,t)=ς_P(s,t) and F(ς_Q(s,t))=f(s,t).
masked_plain_text_def:
Suppose P is a tree and k,l< ω.  Suppose also that there exist ordinals _0⩾…⩾_l such that 
    B_MATH_TERM(P)=ω^ω^_0·…·ω^ω^_l.
      Then for any function f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1,  there exist a subtree Q of P and a function F:l+1→ k+1 such that B_MATH_TERM(Q)=B_MATH_TERM(P) and for each (s,t)∈Λ_2(Q),   ς_Q(s,t)=ς_P(s,t) and F(ς_Q(s,t))=f(s,t).

def:
Fix  $k,l<\omega$. \begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item Suppose $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$, $P$ is a tree with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)= \omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot\ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}$, and $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ is a function.  If $Q\subset P$ and $F:l+1\to k+1$ are as in Theorem \ref{main1}, $j\leqslant k$,  $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, and $\alpha =\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)}\cdot \ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ then there exists a subtree $R$ of $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(R)=\alpha$  such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(R)}\equiv j$.   Here we obey the convention that if $A=\varnothing$, $\alpha=1$.     \item Let $F:l+1\to k+1$ be a function.   Fix  $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ and a tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot\ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}$. Define $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ by $f(s,t)=F(\varsigma_P(s,t)).$  If $j\leqslant k$, $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, $\alpha=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)}\cdot \ldots \cdot\omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ and $Q$ is any subtree of $P$ such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(Q)}\equiv j$, then $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q) \leqslant \alpha$. \end{enumerate}
\label{slop}
plain_text_def:
Fix  k,l<ω. 
  * Suppose _0⩾…⩾_l, P is a tree with rank(P)= ω^ω^_0·…·ω^ω^_l, and f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1 is a function.  If Q⊂ P and F:l+1→ k+1 are as in Theorem <ref>, j⩽ k,  A={i⩽ l: F(i)=j}, and α =ω^ω^_0· 1_A(0)·…·ω^ω^_l· 1_A(l), then there exists a subtree R of P with rank(R)=α  such that f|_Λ_2(R)≡ j.   Here we obey the convention that if A=∅, α=1.     
  * Let F:l+1→ k+1 be a function.   Fix  _0⩾…⩾_l and a tree P with rank(P)=ω^ω^_0·…·ω^ω^_l. Define f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1 by f(s,t)=F(ς_P(s,t)).  If j⩽ k, A={i⩽ l: F(i)=j}, α=ω^ω^_0· 1_A(0)·…·ω^ω^_l· 1_A(l), and Q is any subtree of P such that f|_Λ_2(Q)≡ j, then rank(Q) ⩽α.

If Q⊂ P and F:l+1→ k+1 are as in Theorem <ref>, j⩽ k,  A={i⩽ l: F(i)=j}, and α =ω^ω^_0· 1_A(0)·…·ω^ω^_l· 1_A(l), then there exists a subtree R of P with B_MATH_TERM(R)=α  such that f|_Λ_2(R)≡ j. def:
Let $\gamma$ be a non-zero ordinal and write $\gamma=\omega^{\ee_0}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_l}$ with $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$.  Let $\gamma_0=0$ and $\gamma_{i+1}=\gamma_i+\omega^{\ee_i}$ for $i=0, \ldots, l$.    For any tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\gamma$, any $k<\omega$, and any $f:P\to k+1$, there exist a subtree $Q$ of $P$ and a function $F:l+1\to k+1$ such that $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q)=\text{\emph{rank}}(P)$ and for each $i\leqslant l$,  \begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item $Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}}=Q\cap (P^{\gamma_i}\setminus P^{\gamma_{i+1}})$, \item $\varsigma_{Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}}}=\varsigma_P|_{\Lambda_2(Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}})}$, \item $f|_{Q^{\gamma_i}\setminus Q^{\gamma_{i+1}}}\equiv F(i)$.   \end{enumerate}

\label{ds9}
plain_text_def:
Let γ be a non-zero ordinal and write γ=ω^_0+… +ω^_l with _0⩾…⩾_l.  Let γ_0=0 and γ_i+1=γ_i+ω^_i for i=0, …, l.    For any tree P with rank(P)=γ, any k<ω, and any f:P→ k+1, there exist a subtree Q of P and a function F:l+1→ k+1 such that rank(Q)=rank(P) and for each i⩽ l,  
  * Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1=Q∩ (P^γ_i∖ P^γ_i+1), 
  * ς_Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1=ς_P|_Λ_2(Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1), 
  * f|_Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1≡ F(i).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let γ be a non-zero ordinal and write γ=ω^_0+… +ω^_l with _0⩾…⩾_l.  Let γ_0=0 and γ_i+1=γ_i+ω^_i for i=0, …, l.    For any tree P with B_MATH_TERM(P)=γ, any k<ω, and any f:P→ k+1, there exist a subtree Q of P and a function F:l+1→ k+1 such that B_MATH_TERM(Q)=B_MATH_TERM(P) and for each i⩽ l,  
  * Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1=Q∩ (P^γ_i∖ P^γ_i+1), 
  * ς_Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1=ς_P|_Λ_2(Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1), 
  * f|_Q^γ_i∖ Q^γ_i+1≡ F(i).

def:
\begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item Let $\gamma$ be a non-zero ordinal and write $\gamma=\omega^{\ee_0}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_l} $ with $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$.    Let $\gamma_0=0$ and for $i<l$, let $\gamma_{i+1}=\gamma_i+\omega^{\ee_i}$.  Suppose $P$ is a tree with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)= \gamma$, $k<\omega$, and $f:P\to k+1$ is a function.  Suppose $Q\subset P$ and $F:l+1\to k+1$ are as in Theorem \ref{ds9}.   Fix $j\leqslant k$ and let  $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$ and $\alpha =\omega^{\ee_{a(0)}}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_{a(p)}}$, where by convention $\alpha=0$ if $A=\varnothing$ and otherwise $A=\{a(0), \ldots, a(p)\}$ with $a(0)<\ldots <a(p)$.    Then there exists a subtree $R$ of $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(R)=\alpha$  such that $f|_R\equiv j$.       \item For $k,l<\omega$, let $F:l+1\to k+1$ be a function.   Fix  $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ and let $\gamma_i$ be as in $(i)$.  Fix a tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\ee_0}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_l}$ and define $f:P\to k+1$ by letting $f|_{P^{\gamma_i}\setminus P^{\gamma_{i+1}}}=F(i)$.     Then if $j\leqslant k$, $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, $\alpha=\omega^{\ee_{a(0)}}+\ldots +\omega^{\ee_{a(p)}}$, and $Q$ is any subtree of $P$ such that $f|_Q\equiv j$, then $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q) \leqslant \alpha$. Here we obey the same conventions on $\alpha$ and $A$ as in $(i)$.   \end{enumerate}


\label{megatron}
plain_text_def:
* Let γ be a non-zero ordinal and write γ=ω^_0+… +ω^_l with _0⩾…⩾_l.    Let γ_0=0 and for i<l, let γ_i+1=γ_i+ω^_i.  Suppose P is a tree with rank(P)= γ, k<ω, and f:P→ k+1 is a function.  Suppose Q⊂ P and F:l+1→ k+1 are as in Theorem <ref>. Then there exists a subtree R of P with rank(R)=α  such that f|_R≡ j.       
  * For k,l<ω, let F:l+1→ k+1 be a function.   Fix  _0⩾…⩾_l and let γ_i be as in (i).  Fix a tree P with rank(P)=ω^_0+… +ω^_l and define f:P→ k+1 by letting f|_P^γ_i∖ P^γ_i+1=F(i).     Then if j⩽ k, A={i⩽ l: F(i)=j}, α=ω^_a(0)+… +ω^_a(p), and Q is any subtree of P such that f|_Q≡ j, then rank(Q) ⩽α. Here we obey the same conventions on α and A as in (i).

Then there exists a subtree R of P with B_MATH_TERM(R)=α  such that f|_R≡ j.

plain_text_def:
Let γ be an additively indecomposable ordinal.  For any tree P with  rank(P)= γ, any k<ω, and any f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1, there exist a subtree Q of P with rank(Q)=γ and F:λ(γ)→ k+1 such that for any (s,t)∈Λ_2(Q), F(ς_Q(s,t))=f(s,t)  and ς_Q(s,t)=ς_P(s,t).   

That is, every additively indecomposable ordinal is tractable.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let γ be an additively indecomposable ordinal.  For any tree P with  B_MATH_TERM(P)= γ, any k<ω, and any f:Λ_2(P)→ k+1, there exist a subtree Q of P with B_MATH_TERM(Q)=γ and F:λ(γ)→ k+1 such that for any (s,t)∈Λ_2(Q), F(ς_Q(s,t))=f(s,t)  and ς_Q(s,t)=ς_P(s,t).   

That is, every additively indecomposable ordinal is tractable.

def:
Fix  $l,k<\omega$. \begin{enumerate}[(i)]\item Suppose $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$, $P$ is a tree with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)= \omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot \ldots \cdot \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}=:\gamma$, $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ is a function.  If $Q\subset P$ and $F:l+1\to k+1$ are as in Theorem \ref{big show}, $j\leqslant k$,  $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, and $\alpha =\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)}\cdot \ldots \cdot \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ then there exists a subtree $R$ of $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(R)=\alpha$ and such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(R)}\equiv j$.       \item Let $F:l+1\to k+1$ be a function.   Fix  $\ee_0\geqslant \ldots \geqslant \ee_l$ and a tree $P$ with $\text{\emph{rank}}(P)=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}}\cdot \ldots \cdot \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}}$ and define $f:\Lambda_2(P)\to k+1$ by $f(s,t)=F(\varsigma_P(s,t)).$  Then if $j\leqslant k$, $A=\{i\leqslant l: F(i)=j\}$, $\alpha=\omega^{\omega^{\ee_0}\cdot 1_A(0)} \ldots \omega^{\omega^{\ee_l}\cdot 1_A(l)},$ and $Q$ is any subtree of $P$ such that $f|_{\Lambda_2(Q)}\equiv j$, it follows that $\text{\emph{rank}}(Q) \leqslant \alpha$. \end{enumerate}


\label{optimal prime}

def:
[Confusability] Two words ${\bx}$ and ${\by}$, are said to be $k$-\textit{confusable} if 
$D_{k}^*({\bx}) \cap D_{k}^*({\by}) \neq \varnothing.$ 
Similarly, they are said to be ${\le}k$-\textit{confusable} if 
$D_{\le k}^*({\bx}) \cap D_{\le k}^*({\by}) \neq \varnothing.$
plain_text_def:
[Confusability] Two words  and , are said to be k-confusable if 
D_k^*() ∩ D_k^*() ≠∅. 
Similarly, they are said to be ≤k-confusable if 
D_≤ k^*() ∩ D_≤ k^*() ≠∅.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Confusability] Two words  and , are said to be k-B_MATH_TERM if 
D_k^*() ∩ D_k^*() ≠∅. 
Similarly, they are said to be ≤k-B_MATH_TERM if 
D_≤ k^*() ∩ D_≤ k^*() ≠∅.

def:
A word ${\bx}$ is said to be $k$-\textit{irreducible} if ${\bx}$ cannot be deduplicated into shorter words with deduplication of length $k$. In other words, if $\by\xRightarrow[k]{*} \bx$, then $\by=\bx$. 
The set of $k$-irreducible $q$-ary words is denoted by ${\rm Irr}_{k}(q)$ and the set of $k$-irreducible words of length $n$ is denoted by ${\rm Irr}_{k}(n,q)$.
The $k$-ancestors of ${\bx} \in \Sigma_q^*$ that are $k$-irreducible words are called the $k$-\textit{roots} of 
${\bx}$. The set of $k$-roots of $\bx$ is denoted by $R_{k}({\bx})$.
In a similar fashion, we have the definitions of ${\le}k$-{\em irreducible} words and ${\le}k$-roots of $\bx$, and 
the notation ${\rm Irr}_{\le k}(q)$, ${\rm Irr}_{\le k}(n,q)$, and $R_{\le k}(\bx)$.

The set of k-irreducible q-ary words is denoted by Irr_k(q) and the set of k-irreducible words of length n is denoted by Irr_k(n,q).
The k-ancestors of ∈Σ_q^* that are k-irreducible words are called the k-roots of 
. The set of k-roots of  is denoted by R_k().
In a similar fashion, we have the definitions of ≤k-irreducible words and ≤k-roots of , and 
the notation Irr_≤ k(q), Irr_≤ k(n,q), and R_≤ k().
masked_plain_text_def:
A word  is said to be k-B_MATH_TERM if  cannot be deduplicated into shorter words with deduplication of length k. In other words, if [k]*, then =. 
The set of k-irreducible q-ary words is denoted by Irr_k(q) and the set of k-irreducible words of length n is denoted by Irr_k(n,q).
The k-ancestors of ∈Σ_q^* that are k-irreducible words are called the k-B_MATH_TERM of 
. The set of k-roots of  is denoted by R_k().
In a similar fashion, we have the definitions of ≤k-irreducible words and ≤k-roots of , and 
the notation Irr_≤ k(q), Irr_≤ k(n,q), and R_≤ k().

def:
\label{def:cluster}
A \textit{$k$-cluster}\index{$k$-cluster} $C$ is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:

\begin{itemize}
\item All vertices of $C$ have degree at most 6.

\item Vertices which are not on the boundary of $C$ have degree~5 or~6.

\item $C$ contains exactly $k$ vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.

\item No two vertices with degree~5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.

\item Vertices with degree~5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.

\item Between any two vertices $a,b$ of $C$ which have degree~5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path $P$ from $a$ to $b$ so that each edge on $P$ contains exactly one vertex with degree~5 which is not in the boundary.

\item No subgraph of $C$ is a $k$-cluster.

\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
A k-clusterk-cluster C is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:



  * All vertices of C have degree at most 6.


  * Vertices which are not on the boundary of C have degree 5 or 6.


  * C contains exactly k vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.


  * No two vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.


  * Vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.


  * Between any two vertices a,b of C which have degree 5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path P from a to b so that each edge on P contains exactly one vertex with degree 5 which is not in the boundary.


  * No subgraph of C is a k-cluster.
masked_plain_text_def:
A k-B_MATH_TERMk-B_MATH_TERM C is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:



  * All vertices of C have degree at most 6.


  * Vertices which are not on the boundary of C have degree 5 or 6.


  * C contains exactly k vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.


  * No two vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.


  * Vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.


  * Between any two vertices a,b of C which have degree 5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path P from a to b so that each edge on P contains exactly one vertex with degree 5 which is not in the boundary.


  * No subgraph of C is a k-B_MATH_TERM.

def:
[Cluster]\label{def:cluster}
A \textit{$k$-cluster}\index{$k$-cluster} $C$ is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:

\begin{itemize}
\item All vertices of $C$ have degree at most 6.

\item Vertices which are not on the boundary of $C$ have degree~5 or~6.

\item $C$ contains exactly $k$ vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.

\item No two vertices with degree~5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.

\item Vertices with degree~5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.

\item Between any two vertices $a,b$ of $C$ which have degree~5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path $P$ from $a$ to $b$ so that each edge on $P$ contains exactly one vertex with degree~5 which is not in the boundary.

\item No subgraph of $C$ is a $k$-cluster.

\end{itemize}

A k-clusterk-cluster C is a plane graph where all faces except one exterior face are triangles and that has the following properties:



  * All vertices of C have degree at most 6.


  * Vertices which are not on the boundary of C have degree 5 or 6.


  * C contains exactly k vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary.


  * No two vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are adjacent.


  * Vertices with degree 5 which are not on the boundary are at distance at least 2 from the boundary.


  * Between any two vertices a,b of C which have degree 5 and which are not on the boundary, there is a path P from a to b so that each edge on P contains exactly one vertex with degree 5 which is not in the boundary.


  * No subgraph of C is a k-cluster.

def:
An abstract simplicial complex $\Delta$ over a set $S$ is a collection of subsets 
of $S$ such that, if $\sigma \in \Delta$ and $\tau \subseteq \sigma$, then $\tau \in \Delta$. Each $S \in \Delta$ is a \emph{face}, and 
faces of size one are vertices.

An abstract simplicial complex Δ over a set S is a collection of subsets 
of S such that, if σ∈Δ and τ⊆σ, then τ∈Δ. Each S ∈Δ is a face, and 
faces of size one are vertices.

faces of size one are vertices.

def:
[$k$-matching]
\label{defn:1}
Let $\mathcal{H}=(V,\mathcal{E})$ be an $r$-uniform hypergraph on $n$ vertices and fix a positive integer 
$k$ such that $1\le k\le r$. A $k$-\emph{matching} of $\mathcal{H}$ is a collection of edges $E_{1},\ldots,E_{j}\in\mathcal{E}$ such that every $T\in\binom{V}{k}$ is contained in at most one $E_{i}, i\in\{1,\ldots,j\}$. The maximum cardinality of a $k$-matching in a hypergraph, $\mathcal{H}$, is its $k$-\emph{matching number} and is denoted by $\nu_{k}(\mathcal{H})$.
plain_text_def:
[k-matching]

Let ℋ=(V,ℰ) be an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices and fix a positive integer 
k such that 1≤ k≤ r. A k-matching of ℋ is a collection of edges E_1,…,E_j∈ℰ such that every T∈Vk is contained in at most one E_i, i∈{1,…,j}. The maximum cardinality of a k-matching in a hypergraph, ℋ, is its k-matching number and is denoted by ν_k(ℋ).

[k-matching]

Let ℋ=(V,ℰ) be an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices and fix a positive integer

def: We define the polynomial $P_{M,j}(Z)$ by letting $P_{M,0}(Z)=1$ and \[P_{M,j}(Z)=(-1)^j\sum_{|\sigma|=j}\sum_{\gamma\subseteq\sigma}(-1)^{|\gamma|}Z^{n_M(\gamma)} \text{ for }1\geq j\geq n.\] We shall refer to $P_{M,j}$ as the $j^{th}$ \emph{generalized weight polynomial}, or just \emph{GWP}, of $M$.

def:
Let $ V = \{v_1,\dots,v_n\}$ be a finite set. A \textit{simplicial complex} $\Delta$ on $V$ is a collection of subsets of $V$ such that $F \in \Delta$ whenever $F \subset G$ for some $G \in \Delta$, and such that $\{v_i\} \in \Delta$ for $i=1,\dots,n$.\\
The elements of $\Delta$ are called \textit{faces}. The \textit{dimension of a face $F$}, dim$F$, is the number $\arrowvert F\arrowvert -1$. The \textit{dimension of $\Delta$} is \[\text{dim}\Delta=\text{max}\{\text{dim}F : F\in \Delta \}.\] The maximal faces under inclusion are called the \textit{facets} of the simplicial complex. The set of facets is denoted by $\Im (\Delta)$. A subcomplex $\Gamma$ of $\Delta$ is called a \textit{subcomplex of maximal dimension} (\emph{SMD} for short) if $\Im (\Gamma)\subset \Im (\Delta)$.
plain_text_def:
Let V = {v_1,…,v_n} be a finite set. A simplicial complex Δ on V is a collection of subsets of V such that F ∈Δ whenever F ⊂ G for some G ∈Δ, and such that {v_i}∈Δ for i=1,…,n.

The elements of Δ are called faces. The dimension of a face F, dimF, is the number F -1. The dimension of Δ is 
    dimΔ=max{dimF : F∈Δ}.
 The maximal faces under inclusion are called the facets of the simplicial complex. The set of facets is denoted by (Δ). A subcomplex Γ of Δ is called a subcomplex of maximal dimension (SMD for short) if (Γ)⊂ (Δ).
masked_plain_text_def:
Let V = {v_1,…,v_n} be a finite set. A simplicial complex Δ on V is a collection of subsets of V such that F ∈Δ whenever F ⊂ G for some G ∈Δ, and such that {v_i}∈Δ for i=1,…,n.

The elements of Δ are called faces. The dimension of a face F, dimF, is the number F -1. The dimension of Δ is 
    dimΔ=max{dimF : F∈Δ}.
 The maximal faces under inclusion are called the facets of the simplicial complex. The set of facets is denoted by (Δ). A subcomplex Γ of Δ is called a subcomplex of maximal dimension (B_MATH_TERM for short) if (Γ)⊂ (Δ).

def:
Let $\Delta$ be a simplicial complex. A face $F \in \Im (\Delta)$ is called a \textit{leaf of $\Delta$} iff there exists $G \in \Im (\Delta)$ such that $ (H\cap F) \subset (G \cap F)$ for all $H \in \Im (\Delta)$. A face $G$ with the above property is called a \textit{ branch of $F$}.

Furthermore $\Delta$ is called a \textit{quasi-forest} if there exists a total order $\Im (\Delta)=\{F_1,\dots,F_m\}$ such that $F_i$ is a leaf of $\Gamma$, where  $\Gamma$ is the SMD  with $\Im (\Gamma)=\{F_1,\dots,F_i\}$ for all $i=1,\dots,m$. This order is called a \textit{leaf order} of the quasi-forest. A connected quasi-forest is called a \emph{quasi-tree}.\\
plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex. A face F ∈ (Δ) is called a leaf of Δ iff there exists G ∈ (Δ) such that (H∩ F) ⊂ (G ∩ F) for all H ∈ (Δ). A face G with the above property is called a  branch of F.

Furthermore Δ is called a quasi-forest if there exists a total order (Δ)={F_1,…,F_m} such that F_i is a leaf of Γ, where  Γ is the SMD  with (Γ)={F_1,…,F_i} for all i=1,…,m. This order is called a leaf order of the quasi-forest. A connected quasi-forest is called a quasi-tree.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex. A face F ∈ (Δ) is called a leaf of Δ iff there exists G ∈ (Δ) such that (H∩ F) ⊂ (G ∩ F) for all H ∈ (Δ). A face G with the above property is called a  branch of F.

Furthermore Δ is called a quasi-forest if there exists a total order (Δ)={F_1,…,F_m} such that F_i is a leaf of Γ, where  Γ is the SMD  with (Γ)={F_1,…,F_i} for all i=1,…,m. This order is called a leaf order of the quasi-forest. A connected quasi-forest is called a B_MATH_TERM.

def:
\label{d:esp}
Let $\bPhi$ be a set of $d$-di\-mension\-al predicates.
We say that $\bPhi$ is \emph{Erd\H{o}s--Szekeres}
if for every $n$ there exists $N$ such that every sequence
$\seq \aa$ of length $N$  has a subsequence
$\seq \bb$ of length $n$ such that there is a predicate $\Phi\in\bPhi$
that holds everywhere on $\seq\bb$.
Let $\ES_{\bPhi}(n)$ denote the corresponding Ramsey
function, i.e. the smallest $N$ with the property above.

function, i.e. the smallest N with the property above.

def:
\label{zadj}
    If $U$ and $V$ are $Z_n$ instances of length $m$ such that $U \neq V$ and there does
    not exist a $Z_n$ instance $Y$ of length $m$ such that $\Delta(U) < \Delta(Y) < \Delta(V)$ or $\Delta(V) < \Delta(Y) < \Delta(U)$
    then $U$ and $V$ are said to be neighbors.
plain_text_def:
If U and V are Z_n instances of length m such that U ≠ V and there does
    not exist a Z_n instance Y of length m such that Δ(U) < Δ(Y) < Δ(V) or Δ(V) < Δ(Y) < Δ(U)
    then U and V are said to be neighbors.
masked_plain_text_def:
If U and V are Z_n instances of length m such that U ≠ V and there does
    not exist a Z_n instance Y of length m such that Δ(U) < Δ(Y) < Δ(V) or Δ(V) < Δ(Y) < Δ(U)
    then U and V are said to be B_MATH_TERMs.

def:

def:
[Generalized arithmetic
progression-GAP]\label{definition:1}
A generalized arithmetic progression of rank $r$ is a set of the
form

$$Q= \{a_{0} + x_{1} a_{1 } + \dots + x_{r}a_{r} | 0 \le x_{i} \le L_{i}\}. $$

\noindent If all the sums $x_{1}a_{1}+ \dots+ x_{d}a_{d}$ are distinct, we say
that $Q$ is \emph{proper}. If $a_0=0$, we say that $Q$ is
\emph{homogeneous}. (Homogeneous arithmetic progression thus corresponds to the case $r=1$.)  We call $L_1,\dots,L_r$ the sizes of $Q$ and
$a_1,\dots,a_r$ its steps.
plain_text_def:
[Generalized arithmetic
progression-GAP]
A generalized arithmetic progression of rank r is a set of the
form


    Q= {a_0 + x_1 a_1  + … + x_ra_r | 0 ≤ x_i≤ L_i}.


If all the sums x_1a_1+ …+ x_da_d are distinct, we say
that Q is proper. If a_0=0, we say that Q is
homogeneous. (Homogeneous arithmetic progression thus corresponds to the case r=1.)  We call L_1,…,L_r the sizes of Q and
a_1,…,a_r its steps.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Generalized arithmetic
progression-GAP]
A generalized arithmetic progression of rank r is a set of the
form


    Q= {a_0 + x_1 a_1  + … + x_ra_r | 0 ≤ x_i≤ L_i}.


If all the sums x_1a_1+ …+ x_da_d are distinct, we say
that Q is B_MATH_TERM. If a_0=0, we say that Q is
B_MATH_TERM. (Homogeneous arithmetic progression thus corresponds to the case r=1.)  We call L_1,…,L_r the sizes of Q and
a_1,…,a_r its steps.

def:
Suppose that $A$ and $B$ are two sets in some ambient group, and that $K
\geq 1$ is a parameter. We say that $A$ is $K$-controlled by $B$, or that $B$
$K$-controls $A$, if $|B| \leq K|A|$ and there is some set $X$ in the
ambient group with $|X| \leq K$ and such that $A \subseteq (X \cdot B) \cap
(B \cdot X)$.
plain_text_def:
Suppose that A and B are two sets in some ambient group, and that K
≥ 1 is a parameter. We say that A is K-controlled by B, or that B
K-controls A, if |B| ≤ K|A| and there is some set X in the
ambient group with |X| ≤ K and such that A ⊆ (X · B) ∩
(B · X).
masked_plain_text_def:
Suppose that A and B are two sets in some ambient group, and that K
≥ 1 is a parameter. We say that A is K-B_MATH_TERMled by B, or that B
K-B_MATH_TERMs A, if |B| ≤ K|A| and there is some set X in the
ambient group with |X| ≤ K and such that A ⊆ (X · B) ∩
(B · X).

term: Dissecting Young diagrams into rectangular shapes
def:
[\emph{Dissecting Young diagrams into rectangular shapes}]
\label{def:strike-columns}
Let $\lambda=(\lambda_1\ge \cdots\ge \lambda_\ell)$ be an integer partition.
As usual, we denote by~$\lambda'$ the conjugate partition,
i.e., the partition whose parts are the column lengths of (the shape of)~$\lambda$. 
We~then denote by $\tlambda'_1>\cdots>\tlambda'_s$ the integers, listed in the
decreasing order, which appear as parts of~$\lambda'$. 
In other words, $\tlambda_1',\dots,\tlambda_s'$ are all the
different heights of columns
in the Young diagram of~$\lambda$. 
We~denote by $\tlambda=(\tlambda_1\ge \cdots\ge \tlambda_\ell)$
the partition conjugate to $\tlambda'=(\tlambda_1',\dots,\tlambda_s')$. 
To rephrase, the shape~$\tlambda$ is obtained from~$\lambda$ by 
keeping one column of each height,
and striking out the rest. 

We can now dissect the Young diagram~$\lambda$ by vertical cuts into
$s$ rectangular shapes of sizes $h\times(\lambda_h-\lambda_{h+1})$ 
where $h$ runs over the set of parts of~$\tlambda'$
(equivalently, the distinct column lengths of~$\lambda$). 
To simplify notation for the sake of future arguments, 
we denote $h_j=\tlambda'_j$ and
$m_j=\lambda_{h_j}-\lambda_{h_j+1}-1$, 
so that $\lambda$ gets dissected into rectangles of sizes $h_j\times
(m_j+1)$, for $j=1,\dots,s$.
plain_text_def:
[Dissecting Young diagrams into rectangular shapes]

where h runs over the set of parts of '

m_j=λ_h_j-λ_h_j+1-1, 
so that λ gets dissected into rectangles of sizes h_j×
(m_j+1), for j=1,…,s.

m_j=λ_h_j-λ_h_j+1-1, 
so that λ gets dissected into rectangles of sizes h_j×
(m_j+1), for j=1,…,s.

plain_text_def:
[
Floor diagrams marked by pairs of partitions]
Let  be a labeled floor diagram of degree d and genus g. 
Let λ and ρ be two partitions with |λ|+|ρ|=d.
A (λ,ρ)-marking of  is a combinatorial decoration
of  obtained by the following modification of the procedure
used in Definition <ref>. 
We will illustrate the steps of this procedure using a running
example, in which d=4, g=1, λ=(2), ρ=(1,1),
and  is the labeled floor diagram from
Example <ref>:

    (80,15)(30,-4)(25,1.5)(0,0)2(7,0)(1,0)1(17.5,1.75)(2,-1)1(17.5,-1.75)(2,1)1(27,0)(1,0)1


Step 0.
Introduce ℓ(λ) new vertices denoted
v_1,…,v_ℓ(λ):  

    (80,20)(30,-4)(25,1.5)(0,0)2(7,0)(1,0)1(17.5,1.75)(2,-1)1(17.5,-1.75)(2,1)1(27,0)(1,0)1(40,0)2(40,0)*1(42,2)(0,0)v_1


Step 1.
For each original vertex v in , introduce some number (possibly none)
of additional new vertices, and connect v to each of them 
by a single edge directed away from v.
In addition, introduce some (possibly none) edges directed from v
to v_1,…,v_ℓ(λ). 
Assign positive integer weights to all these new edges, so that


  * for each original vertex v in , 
the total weight of all new edges (of both kinds) originating
at v is equal to 1-(v);

  * the weights of all edges arriving at v_1,…,v_ℓ(λ) 

form the partition λ; 

  * the weights of all other new edges form the partition ρ. 
















Thus, the total weight of all new edges is
equal to ∑_v (1-(v))=d=|λ|+|ρ|.

def:
[\emph{Relative Gromov-Witten invariants}] 
\label{def:G-W-two-partitions}
Let $N_{d,g}(\lambda,\rho)$ denote the number of irreducible complex
algebraic curves of degree~$d$ and genus~$g$ passing through 
a generic configuration %${\mathcal P^{\C}}$ 
of $2d-1+g+\ell(\rho)$ points
in~$\CC^2$ 
and having $(\lambda,\Pcal^{\C}_\lambda,\rho)$-tangency to the
$x$-axis (see Definition~\ref{def:tangency-two-partitions}), 
for a given generic collection $\Pcal^{\C}_\lambda$
of $\ell(\lambda)$ points on $\CC\times\{0\}$.
plain_text_def:
[Relative Gromov-Witten invariants] 

Let N_d,g(λ,ρ) denote the number of irreducible complex
algebraic curves of degree d and genus g passing through 
a generic configuration 
of 2d-1+g+ℓ(ρ) points
in ^2 
and having (λ,^_λ,ρ)-tangency to the
x-axis (see Definition <ref>), 
for a given generic collection ^_λ
of ℓ(λ) points on ×{0}.

[B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM]

algebraic curves of degree d and genus g passing through 
a generic configuration 
of 2d-1+g+ℓ(ρ) points
in ^2 
and having (λ,^_λ,ρ)-tangency to the
x-axis (see Definition <ref>), 
for a given generic collection ^_λ
of ℓ(λ) points on ×{0}.

def:
\label{polyclass:def:pegpattern}
        Let $\tro = \tro_1 \tro_2 \dots \tro_n$ and $\ttau = \ttau_1 \ttau_2 \dots
        \ttau_k$ be peg permutations. Say that $\ttau$ is contained within $\tro$ if
        there is a subsequence $\tro_{i_1} \tro_{i_2} \dots \tro_{i_k}$, whose
        entries lie in the same relative order as those of $\ttau$ and whose
        decorations are \emph{compatible}, meaning that $\tro_{i_j}$ either have
        the same decoration or $\ttau_j$ is decorated with a dot.

        decorations are compatible, meaning that _i_j either have
        the same decoration or _j is decorated with a dot.

def:
[\textit{c.f.} Reiner--Stanton \cite{ReinerStanton}]\label{thm:main}
  The triple
  \[
  \left( G_k(V_\alpha), \sum_{\lambda \subset (n-k)^k}
    \wt(\lambda;\alpha,k) ,\ T_\alpha \right)
  \]
  exhibits the cyclic sieving phenomenon.
plain_text_def:
[c.f. Reiner–Stanton <cit.>]
  The triple
  
    ( G_k(V_α), ∑_λ⊂ (n-k)^k(λ;α,k) , T_α)

  exhibits the cyclic sieving phenomenon.

[B_MATH_TERM Reiner–Stanton <cit.>]
  The triple
  
    ( G_k(V_α), ∑_λ⊂ (n-k)^k(λ;α,k) , T_α)

  exhibits the cyclic sieving phenomenon.

def:
\label{def2}
A graph $ G $ is said to be ($k_{1},k_{2}$)-\textit{regular} if $ \textrm{Deg}(G)=\{k_{1}, k_{2}\} $ and no adjacent vertices have the same degree.
plain_text_def: A graph G is said to be (k_1,k_2)-regular if Deg(G)={k_1, k_2} and no adjacent vertices have the same degree.

def: Let $r$ be an integer with $0 \leq r \leq n$. The \emph{$r^{\textrm{th}}$ layer} of the $G$-independent hypercube, $Q^{(r)}(G)$, is the collection of all $G$-independent subsets of $[n]$ of size $r$.

plain_text_def:
Let S⊆T(n,k) be closed under rotations, and let α,β∈S. Then β is a substring of Greedy_α(S) (treated as a cycle) if and only if β is increasable in S to a rotation of α.
  
  Thus, if S⊆T(n,k) is closed under rotations, then S∈𝒢(n,k) if and only if there exists an α∈S such that every β∈S is increasable in S to α.

  Thus, if S⊆T(n,k) is closed under rotations, then S∈𝒢(n,k) if and only if there exists an α∈S such that every β∈S is increasable in S to α.

def:
\label{def:locally}
Let $L$ be a permutation group, let $\Gamma$ be a $G$-vertex-transitive graph and let $v$ be a vertex of $\Gamma$. We denote by $G_v^{\Gamma(v)}$ the permutation group induced by the stabiliser $G_v$ of the vertex $v\in \V\Gamma$ on the neighbourhood $\Gamma(v)$. If $G_v^{\Gamma(v)}$ is permutation isomorphic to $L$, then we say that $(\Gamma,G)$ is \emph{locally-$L$}.
plain_text_def: Let L be a permutation group, let Γ be a G-vertex-transitive graph and let v be a vertex of Γ. We denote by G_v^Γ(v) the permutation group induced by the stabiliser G_v of the vertex v∈Γ on the neighbourhood Γ(v). If G_v^Γ(v) is permutation isomorphic to L, then we say that (Γ,G) is locally-L.
masked_plain_text_def: Let L be a permutation group, let Γ be a G-vertex-transitive graph and let v be a vertex of Γ. We denote by G_v^Γ(v) the permutation group induced by the stabiliser G_v of the vertex v∈Γ on the neighbourhood Γ(v). If G_v^Γ(v) is permutation isomorphic to L, then we say that (Γ,G) is B_MATH_TERM.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Any graph isomorphic to the graph with set of vertices $\{w_1,w_2,w_3,w_4,\\w_5\}$ and set of edges $\{w_1w_3,w_2w_3,w_3w_4,w_3w_5,w_4w_5\}$ is called a cricket.
A graph without an induced cricket is called \emph{cricket-free}.
plain_text_def:
Any graph isomorphic to the graph with set of vertices {w_1,w_2,w_3,w_4,
w_5} and set of edges {w_1w_3,w_2w_3,w_3w_4,w_3w_5,w_4w_5} is called a cricket.
A graph without an induced cricket is called cricket-free.
masked_plain_text_def:
Any graph isomorphic to the graph with set of vertices {w_1,w_2,w_3,w_4,
w_5} and set of edges {w_1w_3,w_2w_3,w_3w_4,w_3w_5,w_4w_5} is called a cricket.
A graph without an induced cricket is called B_MATH_TERM.

def:
\label{2magic}
	A {\em triple-ordered graph} $G_{<_{1},<_{2},<_{3}}$ is called \emph{double-magical}, if there exist two magical graphs $G^{1}_{<_{1},<_{2}}$ and $G^{2}_{<_{1},<_{3}}$ on $V(G)$  such that  $E(G_{<_{1},<_{2},<_{3}})=E(G^{1}_{<_{1},<_{2}})\cap E(G^{2}_{<_{1},<_{3}})$. An {\em unordered graph} $G$ is said to be {\em double-magical} if there exist three total orders $<_{1},<_{2},<_{3}$ on $V(G)$ such that the triple-ordered graph $G_{<_{1},<_{2},<_{3}}$ is double-magical.% We say that $G$ is {\em witnessed} by $(<_{1},<_{2},<_{3})$.
plain_text_def: A triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is called double-magical, if there exist two magical graphs G^1_<_1,<_2 and G^2_<_1,<_3 on V(G)  such that  E(G_<_1,<_2,<_3)=E(G^1_<_1,<_2)∩ E(G^2_<_1,<_3). An unordered graph G is said to be double-magical if there exist three total orders <_1,<_2,<_3 on V(G) such that the triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is double-magical.
masked_plain_text_def: A triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is called B_MATH_TERM, if there exist two magical graphs G^1_<_1,<_2 and G^2_<_1,<_3 on V(G)  such that  E(G_<_1,<_2,<_3)=E(G^1_<_1,<_2)∩ E(G^2_<_1,<_3). An unordered graph G is said to be double-magical if there exist three total orders <_1,<_2,<_3 on V(G) such that the triple-ordered graph G_<_1,<_2,<_3 is double-magical.

def:
[$(K,\mathbf{q})$-bounded]\label{def:bounded}
  Let $\mathbf{H}=(\cH_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ be a sequence of $n$-vertex
  $r$-uniform hypergraphs, $\mathbf{q}=(q_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ be a
  sequence of probabilities, and $K\geq 1$ be a constant. We say that
  $\mathbf{H}$ is \emph{$(K,\mathbf{q})$-bounded} if the following holds.
  % 
  For each $i\in[\binom{r}{2}-1]$ there exists $n_0$ such that for each
  $n\geq n_0$ and $q\geq q_n$ we have
  \[\mu_i(\cH_n,q)\leq Kq^{2i}\cdot\frac{e(\cH_n)^2}{n^2}\,.\]
plain_text_def:
[(K,𝐪)-bounded]
  Let 𝐇=(_n)_n∈ℕ be a sequence of n-vertex
  r-uniform hypergraphs, 𝐪=(q_n)_n∈ℕ be a
  sequence of probabilities, and K≥ 1 be a constant. We say that
  𝐇 is (K,𝐪)-bounded if the following holds.
  
  For each i∈[r2-1] there exists n_0 such that for each
  n≥ n_0 and q≥ q_n we have
  
    μ_i(_n,q)≤ Kq^2i·e(_n)^2/n^2 .
masked_plain_text_def:
[(K,𝐪)-bounded]
  Let 𝐇=(_n)_n∈ℕ be a sequence of n-vertex
  r-uniform hypergraphs, 𝐪=(q_n)_n∈ℕ be a
  sequence of probabilities, and K≥ 1 be a constant. We say that
  𝐇 is B_MATH_TERM)-bounded if the following holds.
  
  For eachi∈[r2-1]there existsn_0such that for eachn≥n_0andq≥q_nwe have
  
    μ_i(_n,q)≤ Kq^2i·e(_n)^2/n^2 .

def:
\label{fin-def} Let $(G,+)$ be a discrete countable abelian  group, let $\X = (X, \B_X, \mu_X, (T_g)_{g \in G})$ be a $G$-system, and let $U = (U,\cdot)$ be a compact abelian group.  Let $k \geq 0$, and let $\X^{[k]} = (X^{[k]}, \B^{[k]}, \mu^{[k]}, (T_g^{[k]})_{g \in G} )$ be the $G$-system defined in Definition \ref{cubichk-def}.  
\begin{itemize}
\item For each $f \in M(\X,U)$, we define $d^{[k]} f \in M(\X^{[k]},U)$ to be the function
$$ d^{[k]} f((x_\w)_{\w \in \2^k}) := \prod_{\w \in \2^k} f(x_\w)^{\sgn(\w)}$$
where $\sgn(w_1,\ldots,w_k) := w_1 \ldots w_k \in \{-1,+1\}$.    
\item Similarly, for each $\rho \in M(G,\X,U)$, we define $d^{[k]} \rho \in M(G, \X^{[k]}, U)$ to be the function
$$ d^{[k]} \rho(g,(x_\w)_{\w \in \2^k}) := \prod_{\w \in \2^k} \rho(g, x_\w)^{\sgn(\w)}.$$
\item A \emph{$(G,\X,U)$-function of type $<k$} is any function $\rho \in M(G,\X,U)$ such that $d^{[k]} \rho$ is a $(G,\X^{[k]},U)$-coboundary.  We let $M_{<k}(G,\X,U)$ denote the space of $(G,\X,U)$-functions of type $<k$, and let $Z^1_{<k}(G,\X,U) := Z^1(G,\X,U) \cap M_{<k}(G,\X,U)$ 
denote the space of $(G,\X,U)$-cocycles of type $<k$.  % We also write $M_{<\omega}(G,\X,U) := \bigcup_k M_{<k}(G,\X,U)$ and $Z^1_{<\omega}(G,\X,U) = \bigcup_k Z^1_{<k}(G,\X,U)$.
\end{itemize}

[$
u$-triangular extremality]
We say that a graph $H$ on $n$ vertices is $
u$-\emph{triangular extreme} if it contains at least $(1-
u)n/3$ vertex disjoint triangles, 
here $0<\varepsilon\ll d\ll 
u\ll 1.$

here 0<ε≪ d≪ν≪ 1.

def:
If $A,B\subseteq V$ and $X\subseteq V\cup E$ are such that every
\emph{A-B} path in $G$ contains a vertex or an edge from $X$, we
say that $X$ \emph{separates} the sets $A$ and $B$ in $G$. More
generally we say that $X$ \emph{separates} $G$ if $G-X$ is
disconnected, that is, if $X$ separates in $G$ some two vertices
that are not in $X$. A separating set of vertices is a
\emph{separator}.
%
plain_text_def:
If A,B⊆ V and X⊆ V∪ E are such that every
A-B path in G contains a vertex or an edge from X, we
say that X separates the sets A and B in G. More
generally we say that X separates G if G-X is
disconnected, that is, if X separates in G some two vertices
that are not in X. A separating set of vertices is a
separator.
masked_plain_text_def:
If A,B⊆ V and X⊆ V∪ E are such that every
A-B path in G contains a vertex or an edge from X, we
say that X B_MATH_TERMs the sets A and B in G. More
generally we say that X B_MATH_TERMs G if G-X is
disconnected, that is, if X B_MATH_TERMs in G some two vertices
that are not in X. A separating set of vertices is a
separator.

def:

$H\subseteq G$ is a 1-factor of $G$ if and only if $E(H)$ is a matching of
$V$.

V.

def:
[Cut-vertex; Bridge]
A vertex which separates two other vertices of the same component is a
\emph{cut-vertex}, and an edge separating its ends is a \emph{bridge}.
Thus, the bridges in a graph are precisely those edges that do not lie on
any cycle.
%
plain_text_def:
[Cut-vertex; Bridge]
A vertex which separates two other vertices of the same component is a
cut-vertex, and an edge separating its ends is a bridge.
Thus, the bridges in a graph are precisely those edges that do not lie on
any cycle.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Cut-vertex; Bridge]
A vertex which separates two other vertices of the same component is a
B_MATH_TERM, and an edge separating its ends is a B_MATH_TERM.
Thus, the bridges in a graph are precisely those edges that do not lie on
any cycle.

plain_text_def:
Let G be a (multiplicative) group and let K≥1. A finite set A⊂ G is called a K-approximate (sub)group if



  * it is symmetric, which is to say that A^-1=A, and contains the identity;

  * there is a symmetric subset X with |X|≤ K such that A^2⊂ XA.

If A generates a nilpotent subgroup of step s then we say that A is an s-step K-approximate group.

If A generates a nilpotent subgroup of step s then we say that A is an s-step K-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM.

def:
If $P$ is a $(3+1)$-free poset, then for each compatible listing $(X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_{r+s})$ of its clone sets and tangles, we can obtain a word in $\Sigma^*$ by replacing each clone set at level $i$ by the letter $c_i$ and each tangle straddling levels $\{i, i+1\}$ by the letter $t_{i\,i+1}$.
It can be seen that any two compatible listings for $P$ are related by a sequence of valid swaps, so the set of these words is an equivalence class under the commutation relations for $M$ (see, \textit{e.g.}, \cite[Chapter~1]{VCT}), and the corresponding element of $M$ is called the \emph{skeleton} of $P$.
plain_text_def:
If P is a (3+1)-free poset, then for each compatible listing (X_1, X_2, …, X_r+s) of its clone sets and tangles, we can obtain a word in Σ^* by replacing each clone set at level i by the letter c_i and each tangle straddling levels {i, i+1} by the letter t_i i+1.
It can be seen that any two compatible listings for P are related by a sequence of valid swaps, so the set of these words is an equivalence class under the commutation relations for M (see, e.g., <cit.>), and the corresponding element of M is called the skeleton of P.
masked_plain_text_def:
If P is a (3+1)-free poset, then for each compatible listing (X_1, X_2, …, X_r+s) of its clone sets and tangles, we can obtain a word in Σ^* by replacing each clone set at level i by the letter c_i and each tangle straddling levels {i, i+1} by the letter t_i i+1.
It can be seen that any two compatible listings for P are related by a sequence of valid swaps, so the set of these words is an equivalence class under the commutation relations for M (see, B_MATH_TERM, <cit.>), and the corresponding element of M is called the skeleton of P.

def:
\label{def:good} 
 A graph $G$ on $V$ is called `\emph{$(n,C)$-good}' if the following properties hold.
 
\begin{enumerate}[$(P1)$]

\item
There exists  a matching $\cM$ of $G[V_0]$ with $|\cM|=2\epsilon n$ such that for all $U\subset V\setminus V(\cM)$ with $\displaystyle |U|\leq  \frac{\delta n}{C^2\log n}$, 
we have $$\Big|\Big\{ \{a,b\}\in \cM \; \big| \; a\sim u, b\sim u \mbox{ for some } u\in U\Big\}\Big|\geq  \frac{C^2\log n}{16 n} |\cM| |U|.$$

\item

 Let $k=1 \mbox{ or } 2$, and $\cL$ be a collection of pairwise disjoint $k$-subsets of $V$. 
 
 If $\displaystyle |\cL|\leq \frac{\delta}{C^k}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$, then, for $V_i$ with $V_i\cap\Big(\bigcup_{L\in \cL}L\Big)=\emptyset$, $i=1,..., 6$, we have that
\begin{equation}\label{eq:P2_1}
|N_{_{\! B(\cL,V_i)}}(\cL)|\geq (1-\delta)C^k\Big(\frac{\log n}{n}\Big)^{k/2}|\cL| |V_i|.
\end{equation}


 If $\displaystyle |\cL|\geq \frac{\log n}{C^{k-1}}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$, then, for all $U$ with $\displaystyle |U|\geq \frac{\log n}{C^{k-1}}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$ and $U\cap\Big(\bigcup_{L\in \cL}L\Big)=\emptyset$, 
the graph $B(\cL,U)$ has at least one edge.

\vskip 1em
\noindent \Big(No requirement is needed when $\displaystyle\frac{\delta}{C^k}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}<|\cL|<\frac{\log n}{C^{k-1}}\Big(\frac{n}{\log n}\Big)^{k/2}$\Big).

\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A graph G on V is called `(n,C)-good' if the following properties hold.
 



  * There exists  a matching  of G[V_0] with ||=2ϵ n such that for all U⊂ V∖ V() with |U|≤δ n/C^2log n, 
we have 
    |{{a,b}∈ |   a∼ u, b∼ u  u∈ U}|≥C^2log n/16 n || |U|.



  * 

 Let k=1  2, and  be a collection of pairwise disjoint k-subsets of V. 
 
 If ||≤δ/C^k(n/log n)^k/2, then, for V_i with V_i∩(⋃_L∈L)=∅, i=1,..., 6, we have that

    |N__ B(,V_i)()|≥ (1-δ)C^k(log n/n)^k/2|| |V_i|.



 If ||≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2, then, for all U with |U|≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2 and U∩(⋃_L∈L)=∅, 
the graph B(,U) has at least one edge.

1em
(No requirement is needed when δ/C^k(n/log n)^k/2<||<log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2).
masked_plain_text_def:
A graph G on V is called `B_MATH_TERM' if the following properties hold.
 



  * There exists  a matching  of G[V_0] with ||=2ϵ n such that for all U⊂ V∖ V() with |U|≤δ n/C^2log n, 
we have 
    |{{a,b}∈ |   a∼ u, b∼ u  u∈ U}|≥C^2log n/16 n || |U|.

 Let k=1  2, and  be a collection of pairwise disjoint k-subsets of V.

    |N__ B(,V_i)()|≥ (1-δ)C^k(log n/n)^k/2|| |V_i|.



 If ||≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2, then, for all U with |U|≥log n/C^k-1(n/log n)^k/2 and U∩(⋃_L∈L)=∅, 
the graph B(,U) has at least one edge.

Λ(g_1, …, g_n) = Λ(g_τ(1), …, g_τ(n));

  * S_[0,1]-invariant if Λ(g_1^σ, …,
g_n^σ) = Λ(g_1, …, g_n) for all Lebesgue measure
preserving bijections σ: [0,1] → [0,1].

def: [Graph Distances]\label{graphdists} The value $f_{G_{k+1,m}}(\bm x)$ is called the \emph{$G_{k+1,m}$-distance of $\bm x$}. When we restrict our domain to some set $\mathfrak X\subseteq \mathbb R^{d(k+1)}$, we call $f_{G_{k+1,m}}(\bm x)$ a \emph{$G_{k+1,m}$-distance on $\mathfrak X$} and we say that $\bm x$ is a realization of this distance in $\mathfrak X$. The set of $G_{k+1,m}$-distances on $\mathfrak X$ is $f_{G_{k+1,m}}(\mathfrak X)$ and we denote it by $\Delta(G_{k+1,m}, \mathfrak X)$.
plain_text_def: [Graph Distances] The value f_G_k+1,m( x) is called the G_k+1,m-distance of x. When we restrict our domain to some set 𝔛⊆ℝ^d(k+1), we call f_G_k+1,m( x) a G_k+1,m-distance on 𝔛 and we say that x is a realization of this distance in 𝔛. The set of G_k+1,m-distances on 𝔛 is f_G_k+1,m(𝔛) and we denote it by Δ(G_k+1,m, 𝔛).
masked_plain_text_def: [Graph Distances] The value f_G_k+1,m( x) is called the B_MATH_TERM-distance ofx. When we restrict our domain to some set𝔛⊆ℝ^d(k+1), we callf_G_k+1,m(x)a B_MATH_TERM-distance on 𝔛 and we say that x is a realization of this distance in 𝔛. The set of G_k+1,m-distances on 𝔛 is f_G_k+1,m(𝔛) and we denote it by Δ(G_k+1,m, 𝔛).

def:
\label{countmisthm}
Let $G$ be a \emph{SCCG}. Then, $G$ has exactly 
\[
|\mathcal{I}|+ \prod_{i=1}^{sc(G)} |C_i -W_i|+\sum_{m=1}^M \prod_{C_i \in S(I_m)} |C_i - W_i|
\]
maximal independent sets, where $\mathcal{I}$ is the family of all independent sets of $\mathcal{W}$ that are \emph{MIS}s of $G.$
plain_text_def:
Let G be a SCCG. Then, G has exactly 

    |ℐ|+ ∏_i=1^sc(G) |C_i -W_i|+∑_m=1^M ∏_C_i ∈ S(I_m) |C_i - W_i|

maximal independent sets, where ℐ is the family of all independent sets of 𝒲 that are MISs of G.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G be a B_MATH_TERM. Then, G has exactly 

    |ℐ|+ ∏_i=1^sc(G) |C_i -W_i|+∑_m=1^M ∏_C_i ∈ S(I_m) |C_i - W_i|

maximal independent sets, where ℐ is the family of all independent sets of 𝒲 that are B_MATH_TERMs of G.

def: Let $G$ be a graph and $L \subset V(G)$. The set $L$ is independent if no two vertices in $L$ are adjacent. If $L$ is not properly contained in any independent set of $G$, then we say that $L$ is a maximal independent set (\emph{MIS}) of $G$.

def:
\label{defSCCG}
A graph $G$ is a simplicial clique covered graph (\emph{SCCG}) if $\mathcal{C}(G) \neq \emptyset$ and $\mathcal{C}(G)$ is a clique covering of $G$.

def:
Let \(G\) be a \emph{SCCG}. 
\begin{enumerate}
\item The connection set, $\mathcal{W}$, of $G$ is the set of vertices that belong to at least two simplicial cliques of $G$.
\item For an independent set $I_m \subset \mathcal{W},$ $S(I_m)$ is the set of all simplicial cliques that are not contained in the closed neighborhood of $I_m$ and $s_m:=|S(I_m)|.$
\item $\overline{S}(I_m)$ is the complement of $S(I_m)\) in \(\mathcal{C}(G)$.
\item For each $C_i\in \mathcal{C}(G)$, $W_i:=C_i\cap \mathcal{W}.$ 
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let G be a SCCG. 


  * The connection set, 𝒲, of G is the set of vertices that belong to at least two simplicial cliques of G.

  * For an independent set I_m ⊂𝒲, S(I_m) is the set of all simplicial cliques that are not contained in the closed neighborhood of I_m and s_m:=|S(I_m)|.

  * S(I_m) is the complement of S(I_m) in 𝒞(G).

  *  For eachC_i∈𝒞(G),W_i:=C_i∩𝒲.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G be a B_MATH_TERM. 


  * The connection set, 𝒲, of G is the set of vertices that belong to at least two simplicial cliques of G.

  * For an independent set I_m ⊂𝒲, S(I_m) is the set of all simplicial cliques that are not contained in the closed neighborhood of I_m and s_m:=|S(I_m)|.

  * S(I_m) is the complement of S(I_m) in 𝒞(G).

  *  For eachC_i∈𝒞(G),W_i:=C_i∩𝒲.

plain_text_def:
Let G_1 and G_2 be sugraphs of a graph 𝒢 such that 𝒞(G_1) and 𝒞(G_2) are non-empty. We say that 𝒢 is the simplicial clique sum (SCS) of G_1 and G_2 if


  * V(G_1) ∪ V(G_2)=V(𝒢),

  * E(G_1) ∪ E(G_2)=E(𝒢), and

  * V(G_1) ∩ V(G_2) is a simplicial clique of G_1, G_2 and 𝒢.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G_1 and G_2 be sugraphs of a graph 𝒢 such that 𝒞(G_1) and 𝒞(G_2) are non-empty. We say that 𝒢 is the simplicial clique sum (B_MATH_TERM) of G_1 and G_2 if


  * V(G_1) ∪ V(G_2)=V(𝒢),

  * E(G_1) ∪ E(G_2)=E(𝒢), and

  * V(G_1) ∩ V(G_2) is a simplicial clique of G_1, G_2 and 𝒢.

def:
[{{\cite[Lem.~2]{Carter}, 
\cite[Thm.~1]{Scherk},
\cite[Thm.~1]{Dieudonne}}}]
\label{thm:linear}
If $G$ is 
\begin{compactenum}[\quad (a)]
\item a finite real reflection group, or 
\item the real orthogonal group $O_n(\RR)$, or
\item the general linear group $\GL(V)$ of a finite-dimensional vector space $V$, 
\end{compactenum}
and $R$ is the set of elements in $G$ that fix a hyperplane pointwise (the \emph{reflections}), then the reflection length
$\ell_R(g)$ of any element $g$ in $G$ is equal to $\dim \im(g - 1) = \codim \ker(g - 1)$.
plain_text_def:
[<cit.>, 
<cit.>,
<cit.>]

If G is 
[  (a)]

  * a finite real reflection group, or 

  * the real orthogonal group O_n(), or

  * the general linear group (V) of a finite-dimensional vector space V, 

and R is the set of elements in G that fix a hyperplane pointwise (the reflections), then the reflection length
ℓ_R(g) of any element g in G is equal to (g - 1) = (g - 1).
masked_plain_text_def:
[<cit.>, 
<cit.>,
<cit.>]

If G is

  * the real orthogonal group O_n(), or

and R is the set of elements in G that fix a hyperplane pointwise (the B_MATH_TERM), then the reflection length
ℓ_R(g) of any element g in G is equal to (g - 1) = (g - 1).

def:
\label{defpolarspace}
A \index{polar space}\emph{polar space of rank $d$}, $d\geq3$, is an incidence geometry $(\Pi,\Omega)$ with $\Pi$ a set whose elements are called points and $\Omega$ a set of subsets of $\Pi$ satisfying the following axioms.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Any element $\omega\in\Omega$ together with the elements of $\Omega$ that are contained in 
$\omega$, is a projective geometry of dimension at most $d-1$. 
\item The intersection of two elements of $\Omega$ is an element of $\Omega$ 
(the set $\Omega$ is closed under intersections).
\item For a point $P\in\Pi$ and an element $\omega\in\Omega$ of dimension $d-1$ 
such that $P$ is not contained in $\omega$ there is a unique element $\omega'\in\Omega$ of dimension $d-1$ 
containing $P$ such that $\omega\cap\omega'$ is a hyperplane of $\omega$. The element $\omega$ is the 
union of all 1-dimensional elements of $\Omega$ that contain $P$ and are contained in $\omega$.
\item There exist two elements $\Omega$ both of dimension $d-1$ whose intersection is empty.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
A polar spacepolar space of rank d, d≥3, is an incidence geometry (Π,Ω) with Π a set whose elements are called points and Ω a set of subsets of Π satisfying the following axioms.


  * Any element ω∈Ω together with the elements of Ω that are contained in 
ω, is a projective geometry of dimension at most d-1. 

  * The intersection of two elements of Ω is an element of Ω 
(the set Ω is closed under intersections).

  * For a point P∈Π and an element ω∈Ω of dimension d-1 
such that P is not contained in ω there is a unique element ω'∈Ω of dimension d-1 
containing P such that ω∩ω' is a hyperplane of ω. The element ω is the 
union of all 1-dimensional elements of Ω that contain P and are contained in ω.

  * There exist two elements Ω both of dimension d-1 whose intersection is empty.
masked_plain_text_def:
A polar spaceB_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM, d≥3, is an incidence geometry (Π,Ω) with Π a set whose elements are called points and Ω a set of subsets of Π satisfying the following axioms.


  * Any element ω∈Ω together with the elements of Ω that are contained in 
ω, is a projective geometry of dimension at most d-1. 

  * The intersection of two elements of Ω is an element of Ω 
(the set Ω is closed under intersections).

  * For a point P∈Π and an element ω∈Ω of dimension d-1 
such that P is not contained in ω there is a unique element ω'∈Ω of dimension d-1 
containing P such that ω∩ω' is a hyperplane of ω. The element ω is the 
union of all 1-dimensional elements of Ω that contain P and are contained in ω.

  * There exist two elements Ω both of dimension d-1 whose intersection is empty.

def: A permutation $\pi\in S_n$ is called $t$-\emph{stack-sortable} if $s^t(\pi)=123\cdots n$. Let $\mathcal W_t(n)$ denote the set of $t$-stack-sortable permutations in $S_n$. Let $W_t(n)=|\mathcal W_t(n)|$.

plain_text_def:
A directed graph D on n vertices is called (n,λ,p)-pseudo-random if the following hold:
    
        
  (P1) (1 -λ)np ≤
        d_D^+(v), d_D^-(v)≤ (1 +λ)np for every v∈ V(D);
        
  (P2) For every X⊆ V(D) of size |X|≤4log^8n/p we have
        e_D(X)≤ (1-λ)|X|log^8.02n;
        
  (P3) For every two disjoint subsets X,Y⊆ V(D) of sizes
        |X|,|Y|≥log^1.1n/p we have e_D(X,Y)=
        (1±λ)|X||Y|p.
masked_plain_text_def:
A directed graph D on n vertices is called (n,λ,p)-B_MATH_TERM if the following hold:
    
        
  (P1) (1 -λ)np ≤
        d_D^+(v), d_D^-(v)≤ (1 +λ)np for every v∈ V(D);
        
  (P2) For every X⊆ V(D) of size |X|≤4log^8n/p we have
        e_D(X)≤ (1-λ)|X|log^8.02n;
        
  (P3) For every two disjoint subsets X,Y⊆ V(D) of sizes
        |X|,|Y|≥log^1.1n/p we have e_D(X,Y)=
        (1±λ)|X||Y|p.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
A $2$-$(n,\kappa)$-\emph{design} $\mathcal{D}$ 
is a pair $(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{B})$, where
 $\mathcal{P}$ is a set of $n$ points, and $\mathcal{B}$ is a collection  of $\kappa$-subsets  of $\mathcal{P}$,  such that each subset of $\mathcal{P}$ of size $2$ appears in exactly one member of $\mathcal{B}$. The members of $\mathcal{B}$ are called blocks.
plain_text_def:
A 2-(n,κ)-design 𝒟 
is a pair (𝒫,ℬ), where
 𝒫 is a set of n points, and ℬ is a collection  of κ-subsets  of 𝒫,  such that each subset of 𝒫 of size 2 appears in exactly one member of ℬ. The members of ℬ are called blocks.
masked_plain_text_def:
A 2-(n,κ)-B_MATH_TERM 𝒟 
is a pair (𝒫,ℬ), where
 𝒫 is a set of n points, and ℬ is a collection  of κ-subsets  of 𝒫,  such that each subset of 𝒫 of size 2 appears in exactly one member of ℬ. The members of ℬ are called blocks.

def:
\label{7}We inductively define a \emph{hereditary }$2$\emph{-clique} as
follows. A singleton clique is a hereditary $2$-clique. If a clique admits a
homogeneous $2$-partition whose parts are hereditary $2$-cliques then the
clique itself is a hereditary $2$-clique.
plain_text_def:
We inductively define a hereditary 2-clique as
follows. A singleton clique is a hereditary 2-clique. If a clique admits a
homogeneous 2-partition whose parts are hereditary 2-cliques then the
clique itself is a hereditary 2-clique.
masked_plain_text_def:

homogeneous 2-partition whose parts are hereditary 2-cliques then the
clique itself is a hereditary 2-clique.

def:
\label{def:arithexp}
Let $K$ be the Cayley hypergraph as above.
A multiset $S'\subseteq S$ is a \emph{$(C,q,\Gamma,\eps)$-arithmetic expander} if 
$$\lambda_{K}\big(\cay^{(t)}(\Gamma, q, S')\big) \leq \eps.$$
plain_text_def:
Let K be the Cayley hypergraph as above.
A multiset S'⊆ S is a (C,q,Γ,)-arithmetic expander if 

    λ_K(^(t)(Γ, q, S')) ≤.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let K be the Cayley hypergraph as above.
A multiset S'⊆ S is a (C,q,Γ,)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM if 

    λ_K(^(t)(Γ, q, S')) ≤.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM O O O O O

def:
[Pattern Theorem;~\cite{Bender1992}]
  Suppose all of the hypotheses of Theorem~\ref{thr:weakpattern} and
  additionally that \(\MapClass\) grows smoothly, \textit{i.e.}\ that
  \(\lim_{n\to\infty}{m_n^{1/n}}\) exists. Then there exists constants
  \(c > 0\) and \(d < 1\) and \(N > 0\) so that for all \(n \ge N\),
  \[
    \frac{h_n}{m_n} < d^n.
  \]
  \textit{I.e.}, the pattern \(P\) is \emph{ubiquitous}.
  \label{thr:strongpattern}
plain_text_def:
[Pattern Theorem; <cit.>]
  Suppose all of the hypotheses of Theorem <ref> and
  additionally that  grows smoothly, i.e. that
  lim_n→∞m_n^1/n exists. Then there exists constants
  c > 0 and d < 1 and N > 0 so that for all n ≥ N,
  
    h_n/m_n < d^n.

  I.e., the pattern P is ubiquitous.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Pattern Theorem; <cit.>]
  Suppose all of the hypotheses of Theorem <ref> and
  additionally that  grows smoothly, i.e. that
  lim_n→∞m_n^1/n exists. Then there exists constants
  c > 0 and d < 1 and N > 0 so that for all n ≥ N,
  
    h_n/m_n < d^n.

  I.e., the pattern P is B_MATH_TERM.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
A q-matroid M is a pair (E,r) in which E is a finite dimensional vector space over a field 𝔽 and r an integer-valued function defined on the subspaces of E, called the rank, such that for all subspaces A,B of E:


  (r1) 0≤ r(A)≤ A

  (r2) If A⊆ B, then r(A)≤ r(B).

  (r3) r(A+B)+r(A∩ B)≤ r(A)+r(B)
masked_plain_text_def:
A q-matroid M is a pair (E,r) in which E is a finite dimensional vector space over a field 𝔽 and r an integer-valued function defined on the subspaces of E, called the B_MATH_TERM, such that for all subspaces A,B of E:


  (r1) 0≤ r(A)≤ A

  (r2) If A⊆ B, then r(A)≤ r(B).

  (r3) r(A+B)+r(A∩ B)≤ r(A)+r(B)
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
A {\it plabic (or planar bicolored) graph\/}
is an undirected graph $G$ drawn inside a disk
(considered modulo homotopy)
with $n$ {\it boundary vertices\/} on the boundary of the disk,
labeled $1,\dots,n$ in clockwise order, as well as some
colored {\it internal vertices\/}.
These internal vertices
are strictly inside the disk and are
colored in black and white. 
An internal vertex of degree one adjacent to a boundary vertex is a \emph{lollipop}.
We will always assume that no vertices of the same color are adjacent, and that 
each boundary vertex $i$ is adjacent to a single internal vertex.
	%\Comment{Melissa changed this convention in order to talk about lollipops}
plain_text_def:
A plabic (or planar bicolored) graph
is an undirected graph G drawn inside a disk
(considered modulo homotopy)
with n boundary vertices on the boundary of the disk,
labeled 1,…,n in clockwise order, as well as some
colored internal vertices.
These internal vertices
are strictly inside the disk and are
colored in black and white. 
An internal vertex of degree one adjacent to a boundary vertex is a lollipop.
We will always assume that no vertices of the same color are adjacent, and that 
each boundary vertex i is adjacent to a single internal vertex.
masked_plain_text_def:
A plabic (or planar bicolored) graph
is an undirected graph G drawn inside a disk
(considered modulo homotopy)
with n boundary vertices on the boundary of the disk,
labeled 1,…,n in clockwise order, as well as some
colored internal vertices.
These internal vertices
are strictly inside the disk and are
colored in black and white. 
An internal vertex of degree one adjacent to a boundary vertex is a B_MATH_TERM.
We will always assume that no vertices of the same color are adjacent, and that 
each boundary vertex i is adjacent to a single internal vertex.

plain_text_def:
Let (i,j) ∈Φ^+ and a ∈. Let

    H_ij^a    = {λ∈ V : (λ, ϵ_i - ϵ_j) = a}
       = {x_1 ω_1 + ⋯ + x_n ω_n ∈ V : x_i + ⋯ + x_j-1 = a}.

The collection of all hyperplanes of the form H_ij^a is called the . The connected components of V ∖∪ H_ij^a are called alcoves. The group generated by the set of reflections about hyperplanes of the form H_ij^a is the .
masked_plain_text_def:
Let (i,j) ∈Φ^+ and a ∈. Let

    H_ij^a    = {λ∈ V : (λ, ϵ_i - ϵ_j) = a}
       = {x_1 ω_1 + ⋯ + x_n ω_n ∈ V : x_i + ⋯ + x_j-1 = a}.

The collection of all hyperplanes of the form H_ij^a is called the B_MATH_TERM. The connected components of V ∖∪ H_ij^a are called B_MATH_TERM. The group generated by the set of reflections about hyperplanes of the form H_ij^a is the B_MATH_TERM.

def:
Given $\eps,\eps_k>0$,
$r,t_0,t_1\in\NATS$, a $k$-graph $G$ and a $(k-1)$-complex $\cJ$ on $V(G)$, we
call $\cJ$ a $(t_0,t_1,\eps,\eps_k,r)$-regular slice for $G$ if
$\cJ$ is $(t_0,t_1,\eps)$-equitable and $G$ is $(\eps_k,r)$-regular with respect to all but at most
$\eps_k\binom{t}{k}$ of the $k$-sets of clusters of $\cJ$, where $t$ is the number of clusters of $\cJ$.
plain_text_def:
Given ,_k>0,
r,t_0,t_1∈, a k-graph G and a (k-1)-complex  on V(G), we
call  a (t_0,t_1,,_k,r)-regular slice for G if
 is (t_0,t_1,)-equitable and G is (_k,r)-regular with respect to all but at most
_ktk of the k-sets of clusters of , where t is the number of clusters of .
masked_plain_text_def:
Given ,_k>0,
r,t_0,t_1∈, a k-graph G and a (k-1)-complex  on V(G), we
call  a (t_0,t_1,,_k,r)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM for G if
 is (t_0,t_1,)-equitable and G is (_k,r)-regular with respect to all but at most
_ktk of the k-sets of clusters of , where t is the number of clusters of .

def:
Let $l, t $ be in $\mathbb{Z}^+$, with $l=2$ or
$l \equiv 0 \pmod{4}$ and $l\geq 8$. The lexicographic product of $C_l$ with
$\overline{K_t}$ is called an \emph{$(l,t)$-cycle}.
plain_text_def:
Let l, t be in ℤ^+, with l=2 or
l ≡ 0 4 and l≥ 8. The lexicographic product of C_l with
K_t is called an (l,t)-cycle.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let l, t be in ℤ^+, with l=2 or
l ≡ 0 4 and l≥ 8. The lexicographic product of C_l with
K_t is called an B_MATH_TERM.

plain_text_def:
The degree D_n of the source or the sink in a randomly chosen series-parallel network of size n generated by the Bernoulli model
has the following probability distribution:

    ℙ{D_n=m} = ∑_j=0^m-1m-1j (-1)^n+j-1p(j+1)-1n-1,   for 1 ≤ m ≤ n.


Moreover, D_n converges after scaling, for n →∞, in distribution to a Mittag-Leffler distributed r.v. with parameter p:

    D_n/n^p D = D(p),   with   D (d)=Mittag-Leffler(p).
masked_plain_text_def:
The degree D_n of the source or the sink in a randomly chosen series-parallel network of size n generated by the Bernoulli model
has the following probability distribution:

    ℙ{D_n=m} = ∑_j=0^m-1m-1j (-1)^n+j-1p(j+1)-1n-1,   for 1 ≤ m ≤ n.


Moreover, D_n converges after scaling, for n →∞, in distribution to a Mittag-Leffler distributed r.v. with parameter p:

    D_n/n^p D = D(p),   with   D (d)= B_MATH_TERM(p).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
The degree D_n of the source in a randomly chosen series-parallel network of size n generated by the saturation model has, dependent on the probability p of occurrences of parallel edge-duplications in the growth rule, the following limiting distribution behaviour.


  * For 0 < p ≤1/2, the r.v. D_n converges, for n →∞, in distribution to a discrete limit D, D_n D=D(p), which is characterized via the following probability mass function:

    ℙ{D = m} = 1/m+12mm p^m-1 (1-p)^m+1,   for m ≥ 1.


  * For 1/2 < p < 1, the r.v. D_n converges after suitable scaling, for n →∞, in distribution to the product of a Bernoulli distribution and a Mittag-Leffler distribution (i.e., the mixture of a Mittag-Leffler distribution and the distribution of a degenerate r.v. 0):

    (2p-1)^2/p^2·D_n/n^2p-1 D=D(p),

with

    D (d)=Bernoulli(2p-1/p^2) ·Mittag-Leffler(2p-1).
masked_plain_text_def:
The degree D_n of the source in a randomly chosen series-parallel network of size n generated by the saturation model has, dependent on the probability p of occurrences of parallel edge-duplications in the growth rule, the following limiting distribution behaviour.


  * For 0 < p ≤1/2, the r.v. D_n converges, for n →∞, in distribution to a discrete limit D, D_n D=D(p), which is characterized via the following probability mass function:

    ℙ{D = m} = 1/m+12mm p^m-1 (1-p)^m+1,   for m ≥ 1.


  * For 1/2 < p < 1, the r.v. D_n converges after suitable scaling, for n →∞, in distribution to the product of a Bernoulli distribution and a Mittag-Leffler distribution (i.e., the mixture of a Mittag-Leffler distribution and the distribution of a degenerate r.v. 0):

    (2p-1)^2/p^2·D_n/n^2p-1 D=D(p),

with

    D (d)= B_MATH_TERM(2p-1/p^2) · B_MATH_TERM(2p-1).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{def:robust}
Say that $M$ is $(i,\lambda,\lambda',a)$-robust 
if for any rainbow matching $M'$
which is $\lambda$-close to $M$,
any $c\in R$ such that $m_c=vt(v)\in M'$ 
with $v\in \cup_{j=1}^i V_j$, and 
any $E_{\textit{fix}}\subseteq M'\setminus \{m_c\}$, 
any $V_{\textit{avoid}}\subseteq V\setminus  V(M')$ 
and $C_{\textit{avoid}}\subseteq C\setminus C(M')$, 
each of size at most $a$,
there is a rainbow matching $M''$ in $G$ such that 
\begin{itemize}
\item [(1)] $c\notin C(M'')$ and $v\notin V(M'')$,
\item [(2)] $M''$ is $\lambda'$-close to $M$,
\item [(3)] $M''$ fixes $E_{\textit{fix}}$,
and avoids $C_{\textit{avoid}}$ and $V_{\textit{avoid}}$.
\end{itemize}
plain_text_def:
Say that M is (i,λ,λ',a)-robust 
if for any rainbow matching M'
which is λ-close to M,
any c∈ R such that m_c=vt(v)∈ M' 
with v∈∪_j=1^i V_j, and 
any E_fix⊆ M'∖{m_c}, 
any V_avoid⊆ V∖  V(M') 
and C_avoid⊆ C∖ C(M'), 
each of size at most a,
there is a rainbow matching M” in G such that 


  (1) c∉ C(M”) and v∉ V(M”),

  (2) M” is λ'-close to M,

  (3) M” fixes E_fix,
and avoids C_avoid and V_avoid.
masked_plain_text_def:
Say that M is (i,λ,λ',a)-robust 
if for any rainbow matching M'
which is λ-close to M,
any c∈ R such that m_c=vt(v)∈ M' 
with v∈∪_j=1^i V_j, and 
any E_B_MATH_TERM⊆ M'∖{m_c}, 
any V_B_MATH_TERM⊆ V∖  V(M') 
and C_B_MATH_TERM⊆ C∖ C(M'), 
each of size at most a,
there is a rainbow matching M” in G such that 


  (1) c∉ C(M”) and v∉ V(M”),

  (2) M” is λ'-close to M,

  (3) M” fixes E_B_MATH_TERM,
and avoids C_B_MATH_TERM and V_B_MATH_TERM.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
[Reduction process]
A reduction process of gadget 𝒢 is a  
of a subsequence 𝒢' of 𝒢^-1, so that

 
  (i) either 𝒢' = 𝒢^-1, 
 
  (ii) or 𝒢'= I(D_3), I(D_2), I(D_1), I(E_4), …, I(E_j) for some 2 ≤ j ≤ 4 
such that I(E_j-1) does not have correct reduction or I(E_j-1) is a cut-obstacle. 

If (i) holds, we say that the reduction process is complete.
Otherwise, we refer to it as j-incomplete.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Reduction process]
A reduction process of gadget 𝒢 is a  
of a subsequence 𝒢' of 𝒢^-1, so that

 
  (i) either 𝒢' = 𝒢^-1, 
 
  (ii) or 𝒢'= I(D_3), I(D_2), I(D_1), I(E_4), …, I(E_j) for some 2 ≤ j ≤ 4 
such that I(E_j-1) does not have correct reduction or I(E_j-1) is a cut-obstacle. 

If (i) holds, we say that the reduction process is B_MATH_TERM.
Otherwise, we refer to it as B_MATH_TERM.

plain_text_def:
[Reduction process — extension]
Let (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n be an ear decomposition of H(G).
A reduction process of L_1, …, L_n is a  
of I(L_n), …, I(L_j) so that

 
  (i) either j= 1, or
 
  (ii) j>1 and I(L_j-1) does not have correct reduction or I(L_j-1) is a cut-obstacle. 

If (i) holds, we say that the reduction process is complete.
Otherwise, we refer to it as j-incomplete.
masked_plain_text_def:
[Reduction process — extension]
Let (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n be an ear decomposition of H(G).
A reduction process of L_1, …, L_n is a  
of I(L_n), …, I(L_j) so that

 
  (i) either j= 1, or
 
  (ii) j>1 and I(L_j-1) does not have correct reduction or I(L_j-1) is a cut-obstacle. 

If (i) holds, we say that the reduction process is B_MATH_TERM.
Otherwise, we refer to it as B_MATH_TERM.

def:
\label{def:Psi-alcove}
 Let $\Psi$ be a finite subset of $V_\Q^*$.  
 %% Changed to V_\Q^* from \Lambda^* to make uniform with 3Polys. --Matthias
 We consider  the  hyperplanes in $V$ defined by the equations
 $$
 \langle \eta ,x\rangle= n \quad \mbox{  for  } \eta\in \Psi  \mbox{ and   }   n\in \Z.
 $$
 A connected component of the complement of the union of these hyperplanes
 in~$V$ is called a \emph{$\Psi$-alcove}.
plain_text_def:
Let Ψ be a finite subset of V_^*.  
 
 We consider  the  hyperplanes in V defined by the equations
 
    ⟨η ,x⟩= n   η∈Ψ   n∈.

 A connected component of the complement of the union of these hyperplanes
 in V is called a Ψ-alcove.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let Ψ be a finite subset of V_^*.  
 
 We consider  the  hyperplanes in V defined by the equations
 
    ⟨η ,x⟩= n   η∈Ψ   n∈.

 A connected component of the complement of the union of these hyperplanes
 in V is called a B_MATH_TERM.

def:
[$(k,\delta)$-linear forms condition, arithmetic setting]\label{def_lfc_arithmetic}
Let $k\geq 2$ and $\delta >0$. We say that a function $\func[\nu]{\ZZ_N}{[0,\infty)}$ satisfies the $(k,\delta)$-\textit{linear forms condition} (or $(k,\delta)$-\textit{LFC} in short) if
\[
\left| \E_{x_{1}^{(0)},x_{1}^{(1)},\ldots, x_{k}^{(0)}, x_{k}^{(1)} \in \ZZ_N} \left[ \prod_{j=1}^{k} \prod_{\omega \in \{0,1\}^{[k]\setminus \{j\}}} \nu \left( \sum_{i=1}^{k} (j-i) x_{i}^{(\omega_i)} \right)^{n_{j,\omega}} \right]  - 1 \right| \leq \delta,
\]
for any choice of exponents $n_{j,\omega} \in \{ 0,1\}$.
plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, arithmetic setting]
Let k≥ 2 and δ >0. We say that a function [ν]_N[0,∞) satisfies the (k,δ)-linear forms condition (or (k,δ)-LFC in short) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1),…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈_N[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( ∑_i=1^k (j-i) x_i^(ω_i))^n_j,ω]  - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}.
masked_plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, arithmetic setting]
Let k≥ 2 and δ >0. We say that a function [ν]_N[0,∞) satisfies the (k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM (or (k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM in short) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1),…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈_N[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( ∑_i=1^k (j-i) x_i^(ω_i))^n_j,ω]  - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, hypergraph setting]
Let δ >0.  We say that a weighted (k-1)-uniform k-partite hypergraph ν satisfies the (k,δ)-linear forms condition ((k,δ)-LFC) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1)∈ X_1,…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈ X_k[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{ 0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( (x^(ω))_-j)^n_j,ω] - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}, with x^(ω) = (x_1^(ω_1), …, x_k^(ω_k) ).
masked_plain_text_def:
[(k,δ)-linear forms condition, hypergraph setting]
Let δ >0.  We say that a weighted (k-1)-uniform k-partite hypergraph ν satisfies the (k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM ((k,δ)-B_MATH_TERM) if

    | _x_1^(0),x_1^(1)∈ X_1,…, x_k^(0), x_k^(1)∈ X_k[ ∏_j=1^k∏_ω∈{ 0,1}^[k]∖{j}ν( (x^(ω))_-j)^n_j,ω] - 1 | ≤δ,

for any choice of exponents n_j,ω∈{ 0,1}, with x^(ω) = (x_1^(ω_1), …, x_k^(ω_k) ).
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O I_MATH_TERM I_MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
Let $G$ be a graph and let $\{c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3\} \subseteq V(G)$. Then a $(c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3)$-\textit{skeleton} is an ordered list 
$S=(C_0, C_2, Z, P_0, P_1, P_2, P_3)$ such that

\begin{enumerate}
\item  $C_0$, $C_2$, and $Z$ are vertex disjoint cycles, $c_0,c_1\in V(C_0)$,  $c_2,c_3\in V(C_2)$, 

\item  for each $i\in \{0,1,2,3\}$, $P_i$ is a path in $G$ from $c_i$ to some vertex  $z_i\in V(Z)$ that is internally disjoint from 
$V(C_0)\cup V(C_2)\cup V(Z)$, 

\item  $P_0,P_1,P_2,P_3$ are pairwise vertex disjoint, and $z_{0}, z_{1}, z_{3}, z_{2}$ occur on $Z$ in this cyclic order.
\end{enumerate}
plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph and let {c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3}⊆ V(G). Then a (c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3)-skeleton is an ordered list 
S=(C_0, C_2, Z, P_0, P_1, P_2, P_3) such that



  * C_0, C_2, and Z are vertex disjoint cycles, c_0,c_1∈ V(C_0),  c_2,c_3∈ V(C_2), 


  * for each i∈{0,1,2,3}, P_i is a path in G from c_i to some vertex  z_i∈ V(Z) that is internally disjoint from 
V(C_0)∪ V(C_2)∪ V(Z), 


  * P_0,P_1,P_2,P_3 are pairwise vertex disjoint, and z_0, z_1, z_3, z_2 occur on Z in this cyclic order.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let G be a graph and let {c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3}⊆ V(G). Then a (c_0, c_1, c_2, c_3)-B_MATH_TERM is an ordered list 
S=(C_0, C_2, Z, P_0, P_1, P_2, P_3) such that



  * C_0, C_2, and Z are vertex disjoint cycles, c_0,c_1∈ V(C_0),  c_2,c_3∈ V(C_2), 


  * for each i∈{0,1,2,3}, P_i is a path in G from c_i to some vertex  z_i∈ V(Z) that is internally disjoint from 
V(C_0)∪ V(C_2)∪ V(Z), 


  * P_0,P_1,P_2,P_3 are pairwise vertex disjoint, and z_0, z_1, z_3, z_2 occur on Z in this cyclic order.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{goninequality}
The gonality of $U(f)$ is at most $\emph{lw}(\Delta(f))$. If
$\Delta(f)$ is equivalent to $d\Sigma$
for some $d \geq 2$, or
to $2 \Upsilon$,
then it is at most $\emph{lw}(\Delta(f)) - 1$.
plain_text_def:
The gonality of U(f) is at most lw(Δ(f)). If
Δ(f) is equivalent to dΣ
for some d ≥ 2, or
to 2 Υ,
then it is at most lw(Δ(f)) - 1.
masked_plain_text_def:
The gonality of U(f) is at most B_MATH_TERM(Δ(f)). If
Δ(f) is equivalent to dΣ
for some d ≥ 2, or
to 2 Υ,
then it is at most B_MATH_TERM(Δ(f)) - 1.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{lwDelta1} Let $\Delta$ be a two-dimensional lattice polygon.
Then
\[ \emph{lw}(\Delta) = \emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) + 2,\]
unless $\Delta \cong d \Sigma$ for some integer $d \geq 2$, in which
case $\emph{lw}(\Delta) = \emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) + 3 = d$.
plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a two-dimensional lattice polygon.
Then

    lw(Δ) = lw(Δ^(1)) + 2,

unless Δ≅ d Σ for some integer d ≥ 2, in which
case lw(Δ) = lw(Δ^(1)) + 3 = d.
masked_plain_text_def:
Let Δ be a two-dimensional lattice polygon.
Then

    B_MATH_TERM(Δ) = B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) + 2,

unless Δ≅ d Σ for some integer d ≥ 2, in which
case B_MATH_TERM(Δ) = B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) + 3 = d.
labeled_def: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

def:
\label{smallwidth}
Conjecture~\ref{gongeneric} is true for all lattice polygons $\Delta$ for which $\emph{lw}(\Delta^{(1)}) \leq 2$.
plain_text_def: Conjecture <ref> is true for all lattice polygons Δ for which lw(Δ^(1)) ≤ 2.
masked_plain_text_def: Conjecture <ref> is true for all lattice polygons Δ for which B_MATH_TERM(Δ^(1)) ≤ 2.
